catalyst.context: Pure TiO 2 and Ni incorporated TiO 2 with various molar fractions were prepared using a solvothermal method, as shown in Fig. 1 28.To prepare the sol mixture, titanium tetraisoproxide (TTIP, 98.0, Junsei Chemical, Tokyo, Japan) and nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO 3 ) 2 A6H 2 O, 97.0, Junsei Chemical, Tokyo, Japan) were used as the titanium and nickel precursors, respectively.Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (0.1, 0.5 and 1.0 mol) was dissolved in ethanol (100 mL).After that TTIP was added slowly to above solution and this mixture was stirred homogeneously for 2 h.The final solution was thermal treated in an autoclave at 453 K for 8 h under nitrogen environment.The obtained precipitate was washed with distilled water and then dried at 343 K for 24 h. In order to determine the structure and crystallinity of synthesized TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 , powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, model MPD from PANalytical) using nickel-filtered Cu Ka radiation (40.0 kV, 30.0 mA) was taken.The morphology of the nanoparticles were examined by a high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, Tecnal G2 F20 S-TWIN, FEI, Netherlands) operated at 200 kV.The existence of elements was analyzed using elemental mapping and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS).The specific surface area (S BET ) was calculated according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller theory that gives the isotherm equation for multilayer adsorption by generalization of Langmuir's treatment of the unimolecular layer.The BET surface area was measured using a Belsorp mini (BEL, Japan Inc.).The pore size distribution was calculated using the adsorption branch of the isotherm by means of Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method.The zeta potential of the material was determined by electrophoretic mobility using an electrophoresis measurement apparatus (ELS 8000, Otsuka Electronics, Japan) with a plate sample cell.Electrophoretic light scattering (ELS) determination was performed in reference beam mode with a laser light source of 670 nm, modular frequency of 250 Hz and scattering angle of 15.The standard error of the zeta potential, converted from the experimentally determined electrophoretic mobility, was typically 1.5 and the percent error of 5.To measure a zeta potential, 0.1 wt of each sample was dispersed in de-ionized water, and the pH of the solution was adjusted with HCl or NaOH solution.The relative molecular diameter size distribution of the various solutions was also measured using this equipment.The zeta potential distribution was obtained by averaging 2 or 3 times.The UV-visible absorption spectra were obtained using a Neosys-2000 spectrometer with a reflectance sphere.Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy was measured to investigate photoexited electron and hole pairs using 1.0 mm thickness pellets of TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 at room temperature using a He-Cd laser source at a wavelength of 325 nm.The adsorption ability of the catalysts for CO 2 gases were measured by the CO 2 -TPD (temperature programmed desorption) experiments using BELCAT (BEL, Japan Inc.).Each catalyst (0.05 g) was charged in the quartz reactor of the TPD apparatus.The catalysts were pretreated at 473 K for 1 h under a He flow (30 mL min A1 ) to remove the physisorbed water and impurities.CO 2 (5 vol.CO 2 /He) gases were injected into the reactor 30 min at rate of 50 mL min A1 at 323 K.The physisorbed CO 2 gases were removed by flow the catalyst samples at 323 K for 30 min.The furnace temperature was increased from 323 to 973 K at a rate of 10 C min A1 under He flow. The photocatalytic tests for reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O were carried out in a circulated liquid photo reactor designed in our laboratory.There are three major systems -photo reactor, gas circulator, and analytic system (Fig. 2).To photoreduce of CO 2 , 0.5 g of TiO 2 or Ni-TiO 2 was added to 1.0 L of water in a Pyrex reactor.UV-lamps (6 A 3 W cm A2 18 W cm A2 , 20 cm length A 2.0 diameter, Shinan, Korea) emitting light at 365 nm were used to irradiate the solution.Supercritical fluid-grade CO 2 (UHP CO 2 ) was used in this study.It is composed of CO 2 99.999, H 2 O 1.50 ppm, O 2 1.50 ppm, CO 0.10 ppm and THC (CH 4 ) 1.00 ppm.Before illumination, the CO 2 gas was initially introduced to purge at the circulatory system.After that, the reactor was closed, and then lamp and gas circulator was switched on to start the experiment.The reaction temperature and pressure were maintained at 303 K and 1 atm.The gas products were analyzed by gas chromatography for every 10 min.After 1 h, the N 2 gas was introduced to remove gases formed in reactor.And then the above process was conducted repeatedly for 3 times.

In order to determine the structure and crystallinity of synthesized TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 , powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, model MPD from PANalytical) using nickel-filtered Cu Ka radiation (40.0 kV, 30.0 mA) was taken.The morphology of the nanoparticles were examined by a high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, Tecnal G2 F20 S-TWIN, FEI, Netherlands) operated at 200 kV.The existence of elements was analyzed using elemental mapping and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS).The specific surface area (S BET ) was calculated according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller theory that gives the isotherm equation for multilayer adsorption by generalization of Langmuir's treatment of the unimolecular layer.The BET surface area was measured using a Belsorp mini (BEL, Japan Inc.).The pore size distribution was calculated using the adsorption branch of the isotherm by means of Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method.The zeta potential of the material was determined by electrophoretic mobility using an electrophoresis measurement apparatus (ELS 8000, Otsuka Electronics, Japan) with a plate sample cell.Electrophoretic light scattering (ELS) determination was performed in reference beam mode with a laser light source of 670 nm, modular frequency of 250 Hz and scattering angle of 15.The standard error of the zeta potential, converted from the experimentally determined electrophoretic mobility, was typically 1.5 and the percent error of 5.To measure a zeta potential, 0.1 wt of each sample was dispersed in de-ionized water, and the pH of the solution was adjusted with HCl or NaOH solution.The relative molecular diameter size distribution of the various solutions was also measured using this equipment.The zeta potential distribution was obtained by averaging 2 or 3 times.The UV-visible absorption spectra were obtained using a Neosys-2000 spectrometer with a reflectance sphere.Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy was measured to investigate photoexited electron and hole pairs using 1.0 mm thickness pellets of TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 at room temperature using a He-Cd laser source at a wavelength of 325 nm.The adsorption ability of the catalysts for CO 2 gases were measured by the CO 2 -TPD (temperature programmed desorption) experiments using BELCAT (BEL, Japan Inc.).Each catalyst (0.05 g) was charged in the quartz reactor of the TPD apparatus.The catalysts were pretreated at 473 K for 1 h under a He flow (30 mL min A1 ) to remove the physisorbed water and impurities.CO 2 (5 vol.CO 2 /He) gases were injected into the reactor 30 min at rate of 50 mL min A1 at 323 K.The physisorbed CO 2 gases were removed by flow the catalyst samples at 323 K for 30 min.The furnace temperature was increased from 323 to 973 K at a rate of 10 C min A1 under He flow. The photocatalytic tests for reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O were carried out in a circulated liquid photo reactor designed in our laboratory.There are three major systems -photo reactor, gas circulator, and analytic system (Fig. 2).To photoreduce of CO 2 , 0.5 g of TiO 2 or Ni-TiO 2 was added to 1.0 L of water in a Pyrex reactor.UV-lamps (6 A 3 W cm A2 18 W cm A2 , 20 cm length A 2.0 diameter, Shinan, Korea) emitting light at 365 nm were used to irradiate the solution.Supercritical fluid-grade CO 2 (UHP CO 2 ) was used in this study.It is composed of CO 2 99.999, H 2 O 1.50 ppm, O 2 1.50 ppm, CO 0.10 ppm and THC (CH 4 ) 1.00 ppm.Before illumination, the CO 2 gas was initially introduced to purge at the circulatory system.After that, the reactor was closed, and then lamp and gas circulator was switched on to start the experiment.The reaction temperature and pressure were maintained at 303 K and 1 atm.The gas products were analyzed by gas chromatography for every 10 min.After 1 h, the N 2 gas was introduced to remove gases formed in reactor.And then the above process was conducted repeatedly for 3 times.

catalyst.context: Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 (0.1, 0.5 and 1.0 mol).Ni-TiO 2 appeared as anatase structure of pure TiO 2 .The peaks observed at 25.29, 37.86, 48.03, 54.75, 62.73, and 69.22, are assigned respectively to the (1 0 1), (0 0 4), (2 0 0), (1 0 5), (2 1 1), and (2 0 4) planes of TiO 2 29.Moreover, there are no peaks assigned to Ni, NiO, and Ni(OH) 2 are observed.This means that nickel ions are incorporated successfully into the titanium anatase framework.Especially, the (1 0 5) plane peak intensity is increased with increasing amount of nickel compared to that of other peaks.This indicates that the Ni ions are inserted into (1 0 5) site by substitution with titanium ions. Fig. 4 shows HR-TEM images of TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 (0.1, 0.5 and 1.0 mol).It is seen that the prepared nanoparticles composed of rhombic shape with size ranging from 10 nm to 20 nm.TEM results do not illustrate any obvious difference in the morphological features between Ni-TiO 2 and pure TiO 2 .The nickel (Ni) content in TiO 2 was checked by EDS.It was not detected in Ni-TiO 2 (0.1 mol) and Ni-TiO 2 (0.5 mol), because of its very low concentration.The detection limit of EDS is also the main factor.However, the Ni content was successfully examined in (1.0 mol).Table 1 shows the atomic composition of elements in Ni-TiO 2 (1.0 mol). The distribution of elements in Ni-TiO 2 (1.0 mol) was confirmed using HR-TEM elemental mapping analysis and the results are shown in Fig. 5.It can be clearly seen that Ti, O, and Ni elements are truly existed in Ni-TiO 2 (1.0 mol). The N 2 adsorption and desorption isotherms and BET surface area of TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 are shown in Fig. 6 and Table 2 respectively.The isotherms of the catalysts are similar to type III curves, hence the prepared catalysts are non porous materials 30.The BET surface area of Ni-TiO 2 (0.1 mol) is higher than that of other catalysts. The BET surface area of TiO 2 is increased with increasing of Ni content.On the other hand, the BET surface area of TiO 2 is decreased at high Ni content.This is ascribed to the following reason: The size of Ni ions is smaller than that of Ti ions.However, when large amount of Ni component is added, the pores of TiO 2 are blocked 31.It is important to study the mobility of nanoparticles in water because the reaction was carried out in liquid phase.Fig. 6 shows the influence of pH on the positions of zeta potential distribution of catalysts.The zeta potentials of TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 suspensions decreased considerably when increasing pH.The surface charges of materials surface is changed from positive in acid solution to negative in base solution.The isoelectric point of Ni-TiO 2 and TiO 2 was respectively at pH 3.8 and 3.9 which aggregation was considerable.The zeta potential value of Ni-TiO 2 was about A30 mV at pH 7. It explains that the catalysts were stably dispersed in solution during reaction (see Fig. 7). Fig. 8 shows the UV-visible absorbance spectra and Tauc plots of TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 .The absorption of pure TiO 2 appears at about 360 nm.For Ni-TiO 2 , the absorption is red shifted with increasing nickel component from 0.1 to 1.0 mol.A hump in the range of 600-800 nm at high Ni content is resulted from the formation of NiO during synthesis of Ni-TiO 2 32.The band gap was calculated using Tauc equation shown in Eq. ( 1) 33. where a, m, A and E bg are the absorption coefficient, light frequency, a constant and band gap energy, respectively.The band gap was estimated from the point of contact of the tangents to the Tauc plots ((ahm) 1/2 versus hm).The band gap of TiO 2 , Ni-TiO 2 (0.1 mol), Ni-TiO 2 (0.5 mol) and Ni-TiO 2 (1.0 mol) were found to be 3.16 eV, 3.11 eV, 3.06 eV and 3.00 eV respectively (Table 2).Fig. 9 shows photoluminescence spectra of each catalyst to understand the recombination of electron and holes pairs.In general, the photocatalytic activity decreases when the PL intensity increases.The catalysts exhibit a strong PL signal about 440 nm with the exited wavelength of 325 nm.The visible spectral emission at 600-700 nm may be related to singly ionized oxygen vacancies.It results from the radiative recombination of photogenerated holes with electrons occupying the oxygen vacancy 34.The PL emission spectrum of Ni-TiO 2 is decreased when compared to that of TiO 2 .This is attributed to nickel atoms capture the excited electrons and reduce the electron-hole recombination process 35.The PL intensity of Ni-TiO 2 (0.1 mol) is the smallest when compared to other catalysts.However, the PL intensity is increased at higher nickel content.It indicates that high content of Ni do not act as a trapping site to capture the photogenerated electron from TiO 2 conduction band 36.Fig. 10 shows the CO 2 -TPD profile of TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 samples.In general, basicity of catalysts is confirmed from CO 2 -TPD.There is only one peak for pure TiO 2 at 573 K 37, but two peaks are observed at about 523 K (small) and 573 (highest) for Ni-TiO 2 .That peak intensity of Ni-TiO 2 is stronger and shifted to high temperature than that of TiO 2 .Therefore addition of nickel increases the interaction between catalysts surface and CO 2 . Methane yield was used to evaluate the performance of the catalysts.Fig. 11 summarizes the methane yield over TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 photocatalysts in circulated liquid photoreactor system.The methane was just produced when light on and the highest amount was produced at the first time.After 60 min irradiation, the observed methane yields of catalysts order was: Ni-TiO 2 (0.1 mol) Ni-TiO 2 (0.5 mol) TiO 2 Ni-TiO 2 (1.0 mol).The best catalyst was Ni-TiO 2 (0.1 mol) with a maximum methane yield about 14 lmol/g catal during 60 min.However, the yield of methane was gradually decreased in repeated reaction time.This decrease suggests the gradual deactivation of catalysts, and a phenomenon was reported in the literature 38.One of possible reasons is the saturation of the adsorption site which can be activated on the catalysts surface by the intermediate products 39.

catalyst.source: TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 catalysts were composed of anatase structure with size in the range of 10-20 nm.
catalyst.context: In this study, TiO 2 nanoparticles incorporated with nickel was synthesized by a solvothermal method.TiO 2 and Ni-TiO 2 catalysts were composed of anatase structure with size in the range of 10-20 nm.The nanoparticles have large surface area that can be adsorbed with reactant (CO 2 ).The band gap of TiO 2 was decreased when increasing the nickel concentration.The yield of methane on Ni-TiO 2 (0.1 mol) was about 14 lmol/g catal during 1 h.However, the yield of methane is low at high nickel content.It is caused by the decrease in surface area and increase of electron-hole recombination process.The photoreduction of CO 2 is one of the most a fair way to transform CO 2 into useful compounds.The efficiency is considerably low, and further research needs to improve methane yield.
